text: [Music]
oh I think it's been terrible uh you
know I think the whole uh embedding
process was a master stroke of the
pentagon's uh ability to sort of turn
journalists into cheerleaders and um uh
co-opt any sort of of independent
thinking it's very hard as a journalist
to go into a conflict completely um
freshed when you've been through
training courses uh where you have to
learn to put on a gas mask in 9 seconds
flat uh where you are traveling with uh
US troops and you're expecting to be
gassed by these you know terrible Iraqis
uh at any moment and people are shooting
at you as you go through a country and
the people protecting you are the ones
that you're supposed to be writing about
as one part hopefully one part of a
conflict and uh unfortunately the the
the um the coverage was very obviously
one-sided because there was no access to
any other side and um and there was for
a while you know when Baghdad fell and
as it was falling a number of us left uh
our embeds as quickly as possible and
tried to get out and into uh and meet
and live with uh Iraqis in
Baghdad and and that that that happened
for a number of months before the B the
kidnappings and and the situation in in
Baghdad became so dangerous that
journalists were no longer able to go
out and freely report so um once again
we have a situation where most of the
news uh fresh news from journalists at
least Western journalists in in uh in
Iraq is uh being done from behind um you
know behind the lines of American troops
and um with only you know feelers being
sent out for very quick runs into uh you
know the Iraqi um uh residential areas
